10.78.text: The crocodile mummy is one of the most amazing things in our collection.

14.06.text: It is the largest mummy that The British Museum owns

17.08.text: and it...well we haven't seen it on display for over 75 years.

26.78.text: it was excavated at a site called Kom Ombo,

29.70.text: which is located about 50 kilometres north of Aswan

115.06.text: we decided we'd do a CT scan

123.50.text: of the Royal Veterinary College, here in London.

139.36.text: It really told us an awful lot about the mummification

148.44.text: but the upper part of the torso, they've filled with linen packing

152.60.text: but in the CT scans now we can see the stones in its stomach,

157.64.text: the gastrolifts that were used to help it digest its meals

161.36.text: and maybe for ballast as well.

166.68.text: and there were also three very small unidentified metal objects,

171.56.text: and we still don't know what they are.

174.68.text: I don't know if we'll ever find out.

176.46.text: I saw the crocodile, I assessed him or her.

192.34.text: it can travel safely to go on display, it can be on display

199.28.text: and beyond because if I am going to work on it as a conservator

210.24.text: I am looking as far ahead as it's possible for me to look ahead

215.20.text: and so there's a degree of ongoing care with the crocodile.

258.28.text: or something was about to come off and I was able

265.98.text: along with a really stable adhesive we use.

271.62.text: You can use this to insert in to cracks,

274.72.text: to put underneath areas that are delaminating - that are coming apart

280.78.text: and then you carefully weight it in place,

283.58.text: it dries, it's going to stay.

358.32.text: This involved firstly removing of the dust because

365.36.text: and not only is dust visually unnecessary and unpleasant but it obscures the detail.

374.18.text: is carbon rich and under high, humid conditions that might actually

383.30.text: So there's a lot to be said for getting rid of dust, other than the aesthetic.
